title: 104_hr851
content: The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" is established to create a project for rural telemedicine. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network is defined as a network of providers serving physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in rural areas. The network serves physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in a rural area designated as a health professional shortage area or underserved rural area. The Medicare payment for participants is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary will make payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, regardless of location, following a specific methodology. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payments for physician consultative services using signal transmission facilities. Payments can also be made for services provided by nonphysician providers. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. Networks eligible for pilot project if they submit required application and information to the Secretary. Rural area defined as per Social Security Act. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. Priority given to networks facilitating patient-specialist consultations with detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for services under a pilot project, detailing the projects and networks involved, expenses, and number of patients served. A final report is due within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, success in providing specialist consultations in rural areas, and impact on patient access to higher quality care. The Secretary's report to Congress on pilot projects must include details on specialist consultations in rural areas, impact on patient care quality, and recommendations for changes in the medicare program related to telemedicine. Authorization of $51,000,000 from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a demonstration project under the Social Security Act. Up to $1,000,000 can be used for administrative purposes, including report submissions.
